awd_titl_txt: Improving the Success of Low-Income Students in a Cybersecurity Program
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "Improving the Success of Low-Income Students in a Cybersecurity Program" project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  The program targets students in the Cybersecurity program at Old Dominion University. This five-year S-STEM Track 2 project will fund up to 18 scholarships and will provide students with academic support through mentoring and other program activities. 

This S-STEM program at Old Dominion University consists of the scholarship program, the support systems, and a strong evaluation and research plan. It aims to accomplish the following outcomes: (1) generate knowledge about the effectiveness of curricular and extracurricular activities that increase retention and graduation of low-income students from three specific groups: military-affiliated, first-generation, and underrepresented minority students; (2) develop a student-support approach that solves the challenges in this cybersecurity STEM program, which is inherently interdisciplinary; and (3) implement a program that engages students in hands-on labs, cyber competitions, research, and internships, so that they develop the hands-on skills desired by the cybersecurity industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This S-STEM project at Old Dominion University provides a comprehensive program to cybersecurity students, including critically needy scholarships and strong student support and service, and helps them reduce risk and successfully complete their college education and enter the workforce.  Over the past five years, the project has supported 31 students, exceeding its initial goal of 18 students. Among the supported students, 27 students have graduated with excellent academic records. Among the graduated students, 5 students entered graduate school, and 15 students entered the cybersecurity workforce.

The project demonstrates a satisfactory retention and graduation rate, which positively impacts the cybersecurity workforce pipeline, especially for students who are from underrepresented groups. To foster cybersecurity workforce competency development and prepare students for graduate studies, the program implements a comprehensive support system that adapts to both in-person and remote learning environments. This system encompasses a cyber-learning community, virtual learning platforms, peer and faculty mentoring, and dedicated academic advising. These strategies proved valuable in supporting students, especially during the challenges presented by the COVID-19 pandemic. Furthermore, the program leverages various university support services and integrates faculty from diverse disciplinary backgrounds, providing students with rich interdisciplinary experiences.  In addition, extracurricular activities are strongly encouraged for the students. Various opportunities are provided, including undergraduate research, internships, and cybersecurity competitions. Several scholars took leadership roles in the Cybersecurity Students Association, indicating their growth in both academic and professional spheres.

The program's impact extended beyond individual student success, contributing to broader outreach efforts. The scholar students actively participated in K12 outreach events, serving as role models and inspiring younger students, particularly girls, to pursue cybersecurity careers. 


Last Modified: 07/11/2024
Modified by: Brian Payne
